transcription.text: [Music]
Okay, so thank you very much for having me here. It's an honor to speak at Defcon.
So I remember I've spoken since Defcon 0, Defcon 1, 2, 3,
and I see the crowd is really growing, like doubling every year.
It's really great to see the growing of the Ethereum community.
So I want to tell a little bit about what we are doing at Slocket.
So our goal is to build a decentralized sharing economy.
And since last year I was speaking, a lot of things have happened.
So we have done several projects, one which is worth mentioning a share in charge.
This is a project we did for energy and helped building it.
And this is a platform where people can rent out their private charging station for electric cars,
and that other electric cars use them.
So it enables to help that we have a lot more charging stations,
especially in Germany. And they are already 1,200 charging stations life on the public Ethereum chain.
This is backed up by a large corporate such as energy in Germany.
I think it's one of those rare occasions where a large corporate is using the public Ethereum chain
to connect their assets to it.
So I think this is a really great project.
Another project we are part of is the Energy Web Foundation.
You will hear more about it later today from a talk, so I will not go too much into this.
Another project we did last year, we did, we used the DAO framework in another setting.
And at Siemens, it's a large corporate in Germany, I guess you all know it.
There is a life DAO running there with a lot of people participating inside the Siemens company,
Siemens employees, and they are using this for donating to charitable courses.
So it's similar to a charity DAO that they use the funds they gather together and make voting together
and send it to some places.
So we are working hard with larger corporate in Germany to make them use Ethereum
and help them learn how to develop technologies on top of this.
But this is just one part of what SLOG is doing.
The more important part in my view is our work on the so-called "Universes Share Network".
So what is this about?
Our goal is to connect smart objects to the blockchain by managing the access control in a smart contract
to see who is allowed to use certain devices.
So we know that the number of connected devices is growing and growing.
You have smart logs, you have smart plugs, and a lot of other devices.
And we want to control the access to them via a smart contract,
which can be a payment, can be another logic behind this.
So let me show you the architecture of the Universes Share Network.
So first you have the USN Redshift 3.
And this is completely based on the ES. You could even say it is the ES.
Because we just use the main DAO, which then resolves to access control smart contract.
This is another part here.
And the access control smart contract has the logic inside to rent, sell or share things,
or even pay as you use, connect it to a payment channel,
or just have a white list of friends and family which are allowed to use the object.
But every smart device can be registered in the USN with a nice human readable name,
and then pointing to a smart contract, managing its access control.
Of course, another thing you need is an actually access control device,
because most of the smart objects do not have enough bandwidth and computation
and power to actually run an e-therm even light node.
So for those who don't have it, we have built an access control device
which runs in a theorem like client, it can run an IPFS node,
and it runs a library for home automation, so it can be used to connect to all those devices at home.
And it will also come to this point a bit later.
This access control device is then connecting to the smart device,
or door lock, or other things, and sending a Bluetooth,
ZigBee, or Z-Wave signal to control it.
So that's the basic architecture.
Then of course you have the mobile app.
The mobile app has the purpose of managing the keys,
helping with discovering objects, could be something which you're close to,
NFC, or scanning in an QR code, or something you're not close to,
just showing a map, and you can discover those objects.
So this is the channel architecture.
So we'll go explain a bit more about each of those points.
So first the USN registry, which everybody can use.
It is following a following format.
So it has a device name, an optional device counter,
because we often found that you use one smart contract to manage a lot of devices.
You of course can have one smart contact with a device,
but it's not very efficient, also when it comes to gas costs,
and often you have one owner renting out several objects.
So therefore you have the device name, optional counter, and then the contract name.
And the contract name then resolves to the access control smart contract on the ENS.
So it can look something like this, a city bike number three,
at a bill in bike rental.usn.es.
This is the ID of this smart object, which would then be resolved to the smart contract
and can be managed from there.
So we're very thankful for Nick who developed the ENS,
this really creates system very well sought out and very usable today.
So let's come to the access control smart contracts.
There are a lot of different use cases, and you cannot have them all in one contract.
So actually those smart contracts have only one required interface,
which is similar to the ENS, it's just the supports interface function.
And there you'd say which interface are supported, which can be several,
something like the rent functionality, which is the most basic one,
where people can pay a deficit, use something, and when they are done,
they return it, they get a deficit minus the cost back, and the cost go to the owner.
This is one interface.
Another interface could be to book something in the future,
and reserve something for you.
You can have white listed groups which pay nothing or can use it with a discount.
Or you can just pay as you use.
In this case, you can resolve to an address which is managing a payment channel.
And with this payment channel, you can pay directly without going through the smart contract all the time,
and just pay as you use.
So those are the access control smart contracts.
The access control device, that's something we have played around with a long time.
In the beginning, we just use Raspberry Pies, they are nice,
we can use them for a lot of things, but they also have their weaknesses.
It's just not an industrial-create device, which everyone who has used them for a while knows
that SD card can break and a lot of other things can break.
So we have chosen the Samsung Arctic 7 as a very good chip for our use case.
It has an 8 core 64-bit ARM processor, it has Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, ZigBee, Thread,
everything on this little chip here.
It has 1GB of RAM, 4GB of flash, and this is enough to run an Ethereum-like line
very stable in this device.
And also you can have the IPFS node running in this.
It has Enterprise-class security and has a hardware secure element in it,
which you can use for storing the keys, but you can also use an SMT32 on the chip to do this.
Software, as I said, the light-lined, we have Home, Open Source, Home Automation software running in it,
and of course our use and access control logic, as the other script, a Node.js code.
So this is actually the stuff I showed it here a bit, some of the devices.
This is a 3D-printed box where we have this.
It will show you in a minute how this hopefully works in a live demo.
But let's get to the user interface.
So we think user interfaces are very, very important if you want to target mainstream.
So we hired a very good designer helping us building a nice user interface.
So let's have a moment switching to my phone here.
Let's see if this works.
So you should see the screen of my phone, which is connected.
It seems like it has a very weak side.
I'm glad it worked.
So this, what I show you now, is not the real-life app.
This is the design of the app, and afterwards I show you what we have built so far,
which is about 70 or 80% of the stuff you're seeing here.
So I thought it's important to show you also the design,
to get a feeling of how people can actually use the system.
So in the beginning we have a screen showing you what's some filters like available now
within 0.5 kilometers, certain kind of things.
So if you go into this, it makes some suggestion.
So let's say I want to drink something in the morning.
Well, I'm not a coffee twinger, so I actually may want to have a bike ride to the office, for example.
We can switch to the map view to see what's available in my neighborhood or close to me.
And so let's say I didn't want to rent something.
I can also search for stuff based on time, or just based on which kind of object I want to use.
So let's say I'm in the morning I want to take a bike to get to the office.
So I can go for bikes.
I can check out for the current location.
It shows me several bikes that are close to me, shows the price, shows also when it comes to reputation,
like how many people who use it like actually liked it.
Can I click on the bike and see some information about how far away is the bike, who's the owner?
Is he verified?
So this person, for example, is verified as key base, but we are very open to also use other mechanisms
such as Uport or pick-ups from parity.
It really doesn't matter.
The user can see how he's verified and if he can trust the system or not,
which features all of these kind of things, and then you can click on rent.
You can see how long do I want to rent it, two hours, or maybe even several days.
Let's go for two hours here.
When it comes to payment, of course, Ether is the preferred way of paying it.
But we are aware that not everybody wants to use Ether as a currency to pay it.
So we also say we accept Bitcoin or US dollars using PayPal or credit cards.
And how it would work in the smart contract then is, there needs someone, needs to then
prove that the money is received.
This also can be just the owner.
If the owner says, "Yes, I received the money," I can call it a function in the smart context
that says, "Yes, I received it."
Of course, you have not all the features that you would have if you would have paid in Ether,
such as the depositors hold by the smart contract and only release once you return it.
Those features you only have, of course, if you pay in Ether.
So if you go next, get a summary of what's the bike, the date, how long, the payment,
including a deposit in this case, and then you can just click rent.
So the rent was successful.
I can then go in the view, showing me all the stuff I am currently renting, which is the bike.
I also rented a place in a cobworking space that would tap on the bike.
It would open the screen to actually go in front of the bike, sending a Bluetooth signal to open the bike lock.
So, let's go here, for example, the office space, which I also can use.
Let's say I took the bike, I took the bike to the office, I'm in there now, and so what's next?
How could you also use it?
There's also a way of just looking for objects which are close to me.
So I could check for QR code or even NFC.
So I would click, let's say, there is a nice 3D printer I want to use in the office.
And once I want to use this, I go in front of the thing, it is locked in and able to have a nice,
locked logo on it.
You go there, you click on the near-fit communication, it is showing a device,
because you're standing in front of it, it's a 3D printer.
You can have a look and you can rent it.
So this is just an idea of how this app looks like.
And now I want to show you the version which we have right now.
It's just a moment, it's loading.
So let's see, oops.
Okay, there we go.
So there we have this map view.
We are here in Cancun, just call it a little bit.
So we of course put some objects here.
So this is now the wheel app.
And we want to use this microwave here.
This is what you can see here.
If I click it, it shows me the microwave, which I can then click on and it shows me the price,
0.01 ether per hour, it shows me some features of the microwave.
And I can now rent the slot.
I can ask how long it shows me the calendar.
I just want to, over the one day, not too long.
There, even nine hours is a long time.
I can select the ether account.
I can of course have several ether accounts in the app.
A few of the summary, there's the microwave, the renting time, nine hours, the price,
total costs, looks good.
So I can now rent the object.
This is ending now in a transaction on the blockchain.
And you can see the device, there's nice LED lights going up.
So what this box is, in there we have this access control device.
We have the power plug, power supply, everything in one box.
And the nice thing is what you can do with it, you can unplug something in such as the microwave
and it blows it.
You can actually show a washing machine because the washing machine is a really nice use case.
It's just too heavy to get here.
So that's why we choose the microwave.
But you can think about sharing a washing machine in the shared apartment.
You have a student living there, one guy is buying the washing machine.
Every time he wants to use it, he pays.
And this is completely without even talking to each other.
Having a shared calendar or something like this.
So I want to turn it on.
Let's see if this works.
This is a real life demo.
Yes, it is green.
So it got a signal.
So let's use this.
And make something in the meantime.
So we have a new machine.
So let's use this and make something in the meantime.
So this is the microwave which I just paid for using it.
Running.
So let's show some other stuff.
Go into discovery mode.
You can also go look at the list of things.
And bikes.
Of course, there is an apartment which I may want to rent.
This is the slocket apartment.
The wifi is very slow, so the pictures are loading a bit slow.
But this is a apartment from our hometown, Midwider, Germany.
So it's remotely now controlled.
I can see the price, some features, where it is.
And also, of course, rent this lock.
I can set the date from today until I start here those three days.
So I'm using the payment, I'm using ether.
Show me the summary.
Yes, everything looks good.
Can rent the object.
So now it's also sending a transaction.
This is our office in Midwider, very nice place.
So rent was successful.
And now I have control over it.
So this is the smart log you can see here.
I can maybe put this a bit up.
So we are using a new key smart log.
So we are not a hardware manufacturer of smart logs.
They use existing smart log infrastructure to connect to.
So this smart log here is now, because it's not smart enough to run a client in there,
we have this access control device here, which is just running one of those light lines connecting to the door log.
So let's see if I go now on this log-in apartment, I have control over it since I rented it.
Moment, still loading.
Yes, it worked.
So this is right now locked.
I can now push the unlock button.
This will send a signed message to the spark saying I want to unlock it.
And then the light line needs to verify that it actually did work.
So nope, let's try this again.
The Wi-Fi is a bit shaky.
Yes, okay.
Now the log opens.
I can enter.
And use this apartment.
Okay.
And then on later, if I don't use it anymore, I return it so I don't have access to it anymore.
Okay.
I think also the microwave should be done now.
So I just thought, who wants some popcorn?
Let's hear.
Get some popcorn to enjoy the presentation.
You're welcome.
So let's get back to real presentation.
Okay.
It's a bit small.
But well, so what I wanted to announce today is that we want to start the minimal viable
product now.
It's still not perfect.
So that's not a public release of a product.
Everybody can use it yet.
But if you go on MVP.slock it, you can register to become an MVP user and try the system out.
So that's what we want to do now for the next coming month.
And see, get some feedback, optimize the system until we feel it's really stable.
Those users, MVP users can use it reliably.
And once they feel it's safe, then we are ready to release it to the public and everybody
can use it.
But please register the MVP.slock it and try the system out.
So all of this cannot be done alone because we want to integrate with as much device as
we can.
And so we have a lot of partners and friends from smart log manufacturers, of course, people
in the system, such as Newport or Etherisk and many others.
So we're very thankful for all those people we can work together with.
And of course, I want to mention the trusted IoT alliance, which we are part of, which
are a lot of pride people which are thinking about how we can secure IoT devices today using
blockchain technology by giving them, for example, identities and that you can securely
transact using the blockchain.
And of course, last but not least, I want to thank my team.
The great team of-- I think this is an old picture.
We are about 17 people right now, plus some students and freelancers, so in total up to
20 and working on the system.
And I have really have to thank them for building all of this.
They are a great team.
I think the next couple of months or next year, we can release something which everybody
can use.
And we have mainstream users renting out things and connecting smart objects to smart contracts.
And I think this is something where Ethereum is very good at because maybe mainstream users
will not use either as a main currency, maybe, maybe not, but machines don't care.
And to pay machines, there's something we can really use it for.
And machines can verify the payment and act accordingly.
That's something we want to build together with you.
So thank you very much for your attention.
